awd_titl_txt: An Online STEM Career Exploration and Readiness Environment for Opportunity Youth
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

CAST, the University of Massachusetts-Amherst, and YouthBuild USA aim to create a web-based STEM Career Exploration and Readiness Environment (CEE-STEM).  This will support opportunities for youth ages 16-24 who are neither in school nor are working, in rebuilding engagement in STEM learning and developing STEM skills and capacities relevant to diverse postsecondary education/training and employment pathways. The program will provide opportunity youth with a personalized and portable tool to explore STEM careers, demonstrate their STEM learning, reflect on STEM career interests, and take actions to move ahead with STEM career pathways of interest.
 
The proposed program addresses two critical and interrelated aspects of STEM learning for opportunity youth: the development of STEM foundational knowledge; and STEM engagement, readiness and career pathways. These aspects of STEM learning are addressed through an integrated program model that includes classroom STEM instruction; hands-on job training in career pathways including green construction, health care, and technology.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The goal of the CEE-STEM (Career Exploration and Readiness Environment in Science Technology Engineering and Math) project was to create and test a web-based tool promoting STEM understanding and knowledge as a part of classroom and career training. Our focus is on ?Opportunity Youth,? young people aged 16-24 who have not completed secondary education and are unemployed. In partnership with UMass and YouthBuild USA, CAST developed the STEMFolio tool by applying the framework of Universal Design for Learning (UDL) to design a personalized and portable digital tool for youth to explore STEM careers, demonstrate STEM learning, reflect on STEM career interests, and take actions to move ahead with STEM career pathways. At entry, 93% of YouthBuild students do not have a high school diploma or equivalent; 78% are people of color; 73% men; 41% are court involved; 28% are parents; and 27% are on public assistance. The average reading and math levels are at 7th and 5th grade, and most students are significantly behind in credit accumulation.

STEMFolio was developed using an iterative co-design process in which we shared and tested ideas with our YouthBuild partners. Staff and students provided input at all stages of development. We found this tool needed to be mobile first, to require minimal reading and writing, and have options to access information and demonstrate understanding and accomplishments.  

The resulting STEMFolio platform has four major components:

  1. Through a three-step process called a Challenge, STEMfolio gives each student an e-portfolio where they collect information, chronicle STEM learning in classroom and job sites related to careers, and connect with postsecondary and employment opportunities. 
  2. STEM case stories are located in STEMfolio in a video library. Teachers and students access cases for instruction, learning, and models.
  3. Based on UDL, scaffolds and supports are embedded in the tool to provide access to and assistance with STEM content.
  4. A rubric for evaluating young peoples? understanding of various careers in STEM is available for users to reflect and evaluate Challenge responses.

STEMFolio includes features that enable: (a) raised expectations for Opportunity Youth by aligning STEM competency development with Next Generation Science Standards in sophisticated science practices, (b) strengthening the linkages between classroom STEM learning, real-world STEM experiential learning and STEM career exploration, and (c) flexible digital options for youth, teachers, trainers and counselors to make meaning of their STEM learning and connect to postsecondary and work opportunities. 

Outcomes

Unfortunately, the formal randomized control trial for STEMfolio was rendered incomplete due to the COVID pandemic: collection of post-test data was halted by emergency site closures in spring 2020 However, existing data shows promising outcomes. Students in the treatment condition completed over 150 challenges; each of these was scored using the STEMfolio rubric. From the start to closure of the formal study, we noted an overall improvement in responses regarding student ability to demonstrate (a) evidence, (b) accuracy, and (c) competencies knowledge when responding to challenges. For example, in initial responses for math challenges students averaged a score in ?evidence? of 1.7, while at the end, the average score by the same students was 2.9. This pattern of gradual improvement was seen for accuracy and competency selections across Challenge types (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics and Career Skills). 

We also collected data on use of accessibility and support features in STEMfolio. Features such as text to speech, and speech to text were used by over half of all participants. Media features including video and images were used by nearly all teachers and young people in both creating and responding to challenges. Overall, the usage analysis indicated that both teacher and student were able to navigate, and use supports, accessibility features, and options for expression frequently and successfully.

Broader impact

While STEMFolio was co-designed and researched with YouthBuild USA, the project team has customized the e-portfolio to additional contexts, whereby the underlying software remained the same, but content was changed to align with different career pathways, industries, or educational environments, and to different target populations, The eportfolio was also piloted in Career and Technical Education high schools in Massachusetts and a pre-apprenticeship program in Wisconsin. These additional  applications validated that the tool can be customized and aligned to different industries, and the importance of accessibility supports across all contexts and industries. This pilot was supported by the Department of Labor Office of Disability Employment Policy, and results were disseminated nationally throughout the DOL to workforce development entities and employers engaged in creating inclusive apprenticeship models.

 


Last Modified: 12/23/2021
Modified by: Tracey Hall
